comments.commentBody: So it looks like he paid her off in order to avoid some kind of investigation. What is that called?  Don't politicians usually get into a lot of legal trouble for that?  It doesn't sound right.  In fact, it seems quite illegal, yet since it is Mr. Trump, nothing will happen.  This story will blow by like all the other stories of his corruption and law-breaking.  It is breathtaking to see what Mr. Trump has done and know that he can continue to operate normally as a candidate.

It's called a bribe.  To some people it is more wrong to accept money for your foundation that might possibly be construed as a bribe but that resulted in no actual favor granted than it is to be the one who actually bribes and gets his desired result.  There is something really wrong with that thinking.

So the choice is between electing someone (TRUMP) who donated 25k to be - potentially - in the good grace of an official and an official (HILLARY) who too 2 BILLION DOLLARS for her foundation and 120 million in personal speaking fees from various people, companies and governments that needed her influence and help with various deals.

Where's your proof? Parroting back right wing smears of Clinton i. There is the Internet. Have you tried looking up the Clinton's foundation? It has a rating higher than the Red Cross. They have given millions of their own money to the foundation, and make nothing from it. Their foundation has helped millions around the globe suffering from diseases, disasters and the results of climate change.
Tell me who Trump has helped? Oh, yes, I forgot. He helped himself from being criminally charged by the attorney general of Florida on fraud charges by buying her off.
Didn't he brag about helping himself by declaring numerous bankruptcies on his properties and stiffing contractors, craftsmen, and workers, who were lucky to be paid pennies on the dollars that
they earned?
Where is your proof that Hillary Clinton's speeches resulted in favoritism for those who paid her fees. And while you are at it, explain why you are not calling out GOP politicians who routinely give speeches for high fees.

Made up numbers like "2 billion dollars" is ridiculous. Please provide evidence. The Clinton Foundation has helped many millions receive HIV medicine and malaria medicine, saving lives. It spends 88% of its funding in its entities on charity. It is a public charity that divulges all donors.

I really wish Trump supporters would stay moored in reality for at least a minute or two. Trump got away with openly bribing the attorney generals of both Florida and Texas to drop their investigations of the Trump U fraud. The Texas case was well along when Greg Abbott had the staff drop it after receiving $35,000.

The New York Times has absolutely disgraced itself with its coverage of the right wing smear job about both the Clinton emails and the Clinton Foundation as well as about Bill Clinton's trip to North Korea to rescue American prisoners. There are higher journalistic standards that should be met. Time reveals truth but if Trump is elected in the meantime, a large part of the blame rests on the timid coverage of Trump's crimes by the New York Times and other media, by the FBI and by Congress. The double standard is sickening.

Well, great point! But, of course, in regards to Hillary, untrue. Kinda ruins the rhetoric, don't it? Sorry to rain on your parade, but better luck next time; it usually goes better when you make truthful arguments.
63 days till Trump becomes president.  Keep digging, better find something else.

Pardon me, but the candidate elected in November does not become president until near the end of January when he or she is sworn in. If he ends up convicted of felony fraud before being sworn in...well, I do believe he would face a serious problem getting sworn in.
Trump is behind in the polling averages nationally and in most swing states. Keep dreaming! At least you're in Maui, so you'll still be in paradise even when your candidate loses.
Last I heard, bribery was a felony. This should put him and Bondi away for a few years.

I'm struck by the conundrum of choosing for President a person who has either taken bribes (in a broad sense) to allow an advantage or a favor over another who has bribed others for an advantage or a favor.

So, our President will now be on an equal ethical footing with the Congress, right? Political evolution on display.

I still "Feel the Berne" and wish things could have been different, but alas, USA I knew you well.

That's good, except neither of these describes Hillary Clinton. The media have a LOT to answer for, smearing her with these baseless innuendos and only now - yah, you, NYT - covering the real corruption, which isn't hers.

Oh, such a dilemma! Fortunately, it is not upon us, as Secretary Clinton has neither taken or given bribes.

Unless of course you are referring to campaign contributions, say the Hillary Fund, from which Bernie Sanders happily received donations to his own campaigns.
Yes, and this has been a classic Republican maneuver for many a year.  As soon as it looks like they can be accused of something, they immediately turn around and accuse the other side of it.

Wait, what?  Trump's illegal campaign donations weren't bribery?  But Clinton's legal acceptance as a private citizen of a lot less money than Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush took is what's bothering you?

What this article fails to report is that Trump lied to the IRS about this illegal contribution. He falsely represented on a tax form (there's a picture of the form in the story the WaPo did on the Bondi bribe a freaking week ago!) that the contribution went to a non-political charity located in KS, rather than to the Bondi campaign. If it wasn't a bribe, why'd he try to hide it? And I thought that lying to the IRS could get you more than a slap on the wrist.  Silly me.

When is someone going to ask Trump if he approved and signed the $25k foundation check to Bondi?

Instead, a poor A/P clerk gets blamed for not only issuing a check from the wrong bank account but recording the wrong payee. A/P clerks don't issue checks without authorization and backup.

Trump is lying.

Even more classic Trump, after making the illegal contribution from his foundation funded with other people's money (he hasn't contributed to his foundation since 2008) he claims a tax deduction for the contribution. If Mrs Clinton had done this, there would be 5 investigations already underway, yet somehow, people think she's the corrupt one.  Mr Trump, believe me, not too big to bilk you twice.

Besides it all just being a "brush" this is another example of the New York Times soft pedaling anything Trump while running breathless daily front page stories about supposed ethics problems around Hillary Clinton. The little mistake that Trump's people made in reporting a donation to a similar sounding charity rather obviously confirms that this was a bribe they were covering up. And gifting people for favors is all the supposed no-employee Trump foundation is for.
Well Trump told us all he paid for favors during one or more of the debates. He sure did..

I'm so mad that there's not a single worthy person running for the oval office.
Both Trump and Clinton are horrible people. It's just Trump is lot more horrible.
Hillary is only horrible in media's fever dreams. Trump is a know nothing con man.

Can you even articulate what is so horrible about Clinton--and I mean actually proven facts, and not the decades of smears she's been subject to that allow people to blithely call her corrupt?

How is she corrupt? How is she horrible?

Hillary Clinton was my choice from the moment she announced she was running. I've seen no compelling reason since then to change my opinion. My only regret is that she's not facing a worthier opponent.

Trump and the press has been crucifying Hillary for weeks and weeks for errors of judgement regarding an email server, and a highly rated completely charitable foundation.  Trump commits bribery to avoid investigation of Trump University frauds hat ripped millions off of thousands of unsuspecting students.  This is not a question of :"Well, on the one hand, and then on the other"...Trump is a felon who should indeed be dragged before a jury in a court of law.
"Where  is Batman?"  He's back in the Senate working for the people of Vermont since he lost the Democratic nomination to Hillary Clinton.
All this, and he has the gall to keep yammering about "crooked Hillary"? And that umbrella makes him look totally ridiculous.
What payments?  IF you have any real examples or proof surely you would have included them.

Crook, hustler, womanizer, braggart, liar, vulgar personality, hypocrite, bigot, narcissist, politically naive, etc. But his most troubling quality is his impulsiveness. This man cannot become our next President.

I’d bet trust funds that even Richard Nixon would judge the man not fit for office.

Do Trump's supporters believe that with respect to The GOP nominee, as with respect to stock market investments, past performance is no guarantee of future outcomes?

Or are most of these supporters such low information voters that they are ignorant of Trump's past performances?

Andrew in Salt Lake:
From what I understand from reading the JD Vance book HillyBilly Elegy,
many of DT's supporters seem to only care that he is in a sense outside the DC establishment, since he is not a "politician" and he says it like it is in regard to establishment DC politics of which they are now completely distrustful since both political parties have failed them.
They believe him when he says he will bring jobs back to the US. They are blind to his hypocrisies, such as his manufacturing products overseas and then just saying well that is what he as a business person must do.
All they see is the bravado and the foul mouth......and they like that aspect of him.
They can relate to his rough character and foul mouth and therefore think he is one of them.
Neither party will be bringing jobs back, the writing has been on the wall since the 60's and 70's due to automation and computerization.
Excellent book. A deep insight into a very troubling aspect of US citizens who feel
completely left behind and marginalized, choosing paranoia of anyone outside (including their own who miraculously are able to escape to something better) the clan and drugs.

But he DID hide it. The donation to the pro-Bondi group--made (illegally) through the Trump foundation--was listed for tax purposes as a donation to a charitable organization that had a similar name. (A clerical error, of course.)

Thanks for bringing Trump U back into the limelight, where it belongs.  He has never mounted a defense of that scam, only created distraction by accusing Judge Curiel of being racist.  There are two months to go and Trump's sordid history as a shyster preying on hopeful would-be students should stay front and center.  Trump is no champion of the working class, he is their exploiter!
Yes, thanks for the report. Now, follow up and don't let the story die.
I object to calling Trump a shyster. It is a libel upon all lawyers.

Why the Clinton campaign doesn't talk about Trump University three times a day and four times on Sunday is beyond me.

I've never read about a more slimey scheme to take innocent people's money a few thousand dollars at a time - especially by a man who says he's a billionaire. (Search Trump University on YouTube and you'll be amazed)

The great populist, friend of the common man (ha) engaged in criminal fraud and racketeering. Oh, you hadn't heard those are the charges in his trials coming up in late November? Yep.

Trump University is the bottomless bag of nails to hammer him into his coffin and rid us of this phony.

They won't be locking Hillary up.
No, much more likely it will be Trump sharing a cell with Chris Christy (I believe shutting down part of a public bridge is a criminal activity).

"Hey Donald are you going to eat the rest of your fries? I'm still hungry. "

"I told you many times Chris, Trump never gives anything away. Besides, what's in it for me?"

"Why the Clinton campaign doesn't talk about Trump University three times a day and four times on Sunday is beyond me. "
I saw Tim Kaine on CSpan yesterday (rally in Pittsburgh with Biden)
He talked about Trump U students who trusted Trump and did not get paid, along with all the small businesses that trusted Trump and did not get paid and the condo buyers who Trusted Trump and did not get paid--- his theme that voters shouldn't allow themselves to be conned by Trump.
So, the campaign does talk about it. Problem is, the press doesn't report it. Amy Chozik front page yesterday was the new campaign plane that the press got to ride.

The press, overall, has been more than useless in this presidential race. If this is the way it's going to be from now on, our republic will not be kept. Hear that, Ben Franklin? It's getting close to ending. Hear that, John Adams? Hear that Thomas Jefferson? Hear that George Washington? And all the other enlightened men (for white men) who gave us the foundation for our republic, our supposed 'freedom' (with the constant mass surveillance, we are not free).

It was a good idea, this republic. Sorry, Ben. We blew it. And the press was a big part of that undoing.

Maybe the Clintons don't want to talk about the on-line "university" that paid Bill millions to be its honorary chancellor.  (We do have politicians who aren't scam-artists, just not the ones running for president this year.)
Your hypocrisy knows no bounds, sir.
0 hits tonight!  I believe I figured him out the hard way, however.

I certainly hope Trump's illegal contribution to Ms. Bondi, the Florida Attorney General responsible for pressing charges regarding Trump University, stays on the forefront of this election.

It's the least the Democrats can do given the GOP's years of crucifixion of Hillary for Benghazi which has never resulted in a legal charge of guilt.

And all she did in Benghazi was ignore hundreds of cables from her ambassador warning about the danger to him and the US Embassy there, and asking for more security, withdraw the little security he did have, leaving him and the US Embassy totally unguarded, send no aid during the seven hour attack that killed him and burned the facility, and then lie to his family about the cause of the attack.
But, yes indeed, no indictment.
You just hide behind that.
I think the FBI should investigate and if necessary, hold Congressional hearings.  What is good for HRC and Benghazi is good enough for Bondi and Campaign "donations", don't you think?
Worry not the NYTs will forget this story and move back to HRC the next time she breaks a fingernail.

When it comes to Citizen Trump the more brazen his offense, the more brazen his defense.

Supposedly, he learned that from his father. Fred's credo was simplicity itself. Never admit that you did anything wrong, even if you did. And never admit that you were in the wrong even if you were. Which is why Trump fils behaves with such snarling arrogance and indifference to the truth that some misguided Americans somehow confuse with strength-of-character.

As the Watergate Scandal was heating up President Nixon grandly proclaimed that he was above the law. He didn't say it in the first person, but the third. "The President is above the law". Not just like a king, but an absolute monarch. The U.S. Constitution didn't apply to the President.

A vote for Trump would be a vote for Nixon's theory of the Office of President.

A vote for Trump would be cast for a corrupt, corrupting, corrupted tyrant; with all that implies.

now that the media has pivoted from the avalanche of mystified & jocular free publicity of yore to the avalanche of free publicity of today's "critical" pieces, Barabbas just gets stronger & stronger & stronger.

He learned dirty dealings and discrimination from his father.  It was Roy Cohn, lead lawyer for Joseph McCarthy, who taught him how to 'punch back ten times as hard' and lie, lie, lie.  Trump is just god-awful and yet this contest is so close it is making me nauseous.

@Sophia:

Yes, the Poison Dwarf undoubtedly taught him much. Taught young Donald that the world is a beastly place, so it's cool to have utter contempt for humanity. That the truth is what you say it is.

Cohn unleashed Trump's worst impulses by showing him how to use the law and our flawed legal system to evade any consequences. He probably taught him the finer points of chess, looking five, eight moves ahead, planning the rip-off from the first friendly encounter to "you're fired".

Seduce the mark. Lure him closer until he's in striking distance while testing him, quietly studying his weaknesses and vulnerabilities. Use that to maneuver (aka: "negotiate") him into a vulnerable position, even a kill box. Manipulate him into signing a one-sided contract. Then, slowly rip him off for everything you can get. Finally, dump a ton of abuse on him, blame him for everything that happened and discard him, leaving him face down in the gutter. Then, on to the next one.

"Pump and dump Trump".

More lessons. A few small crimes might trip you up but an onslaught of them, a tsunami, a way of life built around them warps the surrounding environment. That normalizes otherwise outrageous misbehavior, makes it acceptable.

Should others object or fail to acquiesce, bully them into silence, into acquiescing. Bend them to your will. Force them to accept it, and you, for what you are.

Attract like-minded people into your orbit. Uses them as long as it profits you, then discard them too.
Thanks, Jake, we'll all be sure to remember that. LOL

The headline here is just about as nice to Trump as you can get. This was not a "brush with campaign funding rules." It was a bribe. If the Clinton Foundation and done anything close to this the Times headline would at least suggest that it was a bribe. Trump bribed Florida's attorney general. When will the Times report that?
What is being described is a felony.
Makes you wonder if he paid the Times for kind headlines...
A few short weeks before the Election and the answer is NO.  Since these illegal acts occurred months ago, the NYT is basically an accomplice.
From his past behavior, it's reasonable to think that Trump, as President, would find it acceptable to receive bribes.

He certainly loves money enough to do almost anything at all, legal or not, to get more of the stuff. I expect major corruption (the breaking of laws that even a president has to obey) should this man get elected. He has no respect for laws that apply to him but promises to come down harshly on others who break laws. He's a hypocrite.
......and he would brag about it, because he knows from past experience that he will never be held accountable.
